intro: Cacalia trinervia, commonly known as the three-veined bellflower, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia, particularly China and Japan. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in woodland areas and has lance-shaped leaves with three prominent veins. Its root system is fibrous, and it is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens. Cacalia trinervia is also noted for its ability to thrive in partial shade and well-drained soil.
